title: DER Touristik boss vows to "keep what makes Kuoni strong"
text:
DER Touristik boss vows to "keep what makes Kuoni strong" 10 July 2015 Save 
The potential new owner of Kuoni’s European travel business has pledged to leave local practices well alone as he seeks to “keep what makes Kuoni strong”. 
Speaking to German travel-trade newspaper fvw, Soren Hartmann, the chief executive of DER Touristik - the tourism arm of the Rewe Group which is behind the bid, has spoken about future plans for the business. 
However, he must wait for the acquisition to be cleared by competition authorities, a process that is unlikely to be problematic, before he takes control of the company in September. 
And he is keen to hit the ground running, saying that as soon as the deal is done, “Then we will start intensive talks with the management and start to develop the strategy.” 
Hartmann added the integration is expected to take up to three years and he is keen to ensure best practice is spread across the group, with Kuoni’s UK travel agencies being one area others can learn from. 
He said: “We want to be fast but there won’t be any harakiri. 
“I wouldn’t describe it as an integration in all cases. We will see where the Kuoni tour operators can use our platforms. 
“But we can learn as well, for example from the Kuoni specialists and the travel agencies in Switzerland and the UK, which successfully sell high-value holidays.” 
He also told the paper that any synergies following the acquisition would be achieved through operations and production. 
“Sales and brands are local and have to stay like that, we won’t force everything on to common platforms.” 
Once the deal is complete DER Touristik will have bought about 40 different companies from Kuoni with combined revenues of about €2 billion and 1.5 million customers.
